title-group.article-title: Phenomenological modeling of combustion and emissions for multiple-injection common rail direct injection engines

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, India

author-notes.corresp: Pramod S Mehta, Internal Combustion Engines Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai 600 036, India. Email: psmehta@iitm.ac.in

abstract.p: The high-pressure multiple injections in common rail direct injection diesel engines offer a possibility of simultaneous reduction of exhaust smoke and oxides of nitrogen. The purpose of the present work is to develop a phenomenological model to enable parametric understanding of the combustion and emission characteristics of multiple-injection common rail direct injection engines. The model is based on a two-zone formulation comprising of fuel–air spray and the surrounding air. The model predictions for combustion and emissions are validated with measured results of different multiple-injection schedules available in the published literature. The effect of parametric variations of multiple-injection scheduling on emission characteristics are predicted using the proposed model. It is observed that the simultaneous reduction of oxides of nitrogen and smoke is possible with an optimized pilot fuel quantity and dwell between the injection pulses.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Future emission norms require considerable reduction of both oxides of nitrogen (NO x) and smoke from diesel engines. In order to meet emission norms, either engine design changes or after-treatment techniques, such as diesel particulate filter or selective catalytic reduction,1 are employed in diesel engines. Due to fast response and control flexibility of common rail direct injection (CRDI) technology, it is becoming possible to abate the traditional NO x-smoke trade-off problem of conventional direct injection diesel engines. Several experimental investigations2–8 demonstrated the possibilities of simultaneous reduction of NO x and smoke using pilot injection or multiple pulses in the CRDI injection schedules. While Shakal and Martin3 observed that a pilot fuel quantity of 17% of the total fuel injection reduced NO x by over 10%, and smoke from 2.7 to 2.2 Bosch number, Tennison and Reitz4 found that the pilot injection reduced NO x concentration and increased smoke level vis-à-vis the single-injection case. They also found that an increase in dwell between pilot and main injection caused an increase in brake specific fuel consumption (BSFC). From these investigations, not only is a potential advantage of pilot injection in reducing NO x emission evident, it can also be seen that a simultaneous reduction of NO x and smoke occurs for an optimized pilot fuel quantity and the dwell. In experiments with two-pulse split injection, an increase in NO x emission was observed by Hasse et al.5 However, Pierpont et al.6 demonstrated usefulness of an after-injection strategy in controlling increased smoke from two-pulse split injection. In an after-injection strategy, the dwell between main and post-injection controls the trade-off between NO x and smoke emissions. An increase in soot amount is observed if the after-injection is too close to the main injection or too retarded with the main injection.8 However, Tow et al.7 reported a reduction in soot quantity by using a small after-injection pulse. They attributed the effect to an increase in the particulate oxidation rate at a later stage in the cycle. Hence, it is evident that a multiple injection with optimized fuel quantity in each pulse and dwell between the injection phases can provide a simultaneous reduction of NO x and smoke in a diesel engine. Thus, taking advantage of an electronic interface in CRDI technology for maintaining a constant injection pressure and flexibility of injection scheduling with multiple injections, an injection schedule involving timing of injection pulses, the dwell between the pulses and the duration of injection can be suitably optimized for realizing exhaust smoke and NO x reduction without adversely affecting fuel consumption and CO emissions. As the injection schedule in a CRDI engine strongly influences emission, it needs to be optimized. The simple and fast phenomenological models are good tools for optimizing the injection schedule in a CRDI engine. For this purpose, a multi-dimensional computation9 may prove helpful in arriving at a more accurate and detailed solution, but at the expense of computational time. As a precursor to these computations, a multi-zone phenomenological model can be a time-economical tool for understanding the physics and obtaining qualitative trends to facilitate initial design.

In this work, a two-zone phenomenological model is developed for predicting the combustion and emission characteristics of multiple-injection CRDI engines. The applicability of the phenomenological model to the case of multiple-injection schedules has been demonstrated. The model has been fine tuned using multiple sources of data from the literature for single- and multiple-injection schedules.

sec.title: Formulation of the model
sec.p: In the two-zone model, the instantaneous combustion space is divided into two homogeneous regions, the spray and the surroundings, which are schematically shown in Figure 1. The surroundings primarily consist of air. The spray zone appears from the onset of fuel injection and develops gradually due to injected fuel and the air entrainment from the surroundings. During injection, the fuel–air mixing and chemical reaction are restricted to the spray zone. The combustion products formed during combustion of the ignitable fuel–air mixture in the spray region also influence the spray growth. The combustion occurring in the spray region is kinetics controlled during the premixed phase and mixing controlled in the subsequent phase. In the post-injection phase, the fuel–air mixing and burning rates are evaluated based on the turbulent mixing considerations of the whole cylinder contents.

While the processes of atomization, evaporation and air entrainment are modeled to predict spray mixing, the turbulent mixing is based on a standard turbulent kinetic energy (k) and dissipation (ϵ) formulation. From the instant of start of fuel injection, the instantaneous volume, pressure, temperature and mass of the spray zone and surroundings are obtained from the thermodynamic analysis assuming uniform pressure across the cylinder content. The present formulation is a sequel to an earlier single-zone formulation10 for multiple injections that provided very encouraging trends of mixing and energy release rates for the first-order investigation. The details of the proposed model formulation are discussed in the following sections.

sec.title: Spray model
sec.p: In the spray model, the fuel injected in each time step (0.10 degree crank angle (°CA)) is treated as a parcel of droplets with its representative mean diameter expressed in terms of the Sauter mean diameter (Ds). A parcel is a cluster of droplets with all identical properties (such as diameter, temperature, etc.). The parcel tracking approach used here is similar to the one generally used in multi-dimensional models.
The Sauter mean diameter, Ds, of a parcel is estimated using the correlation11
where
and
where uj is the spray jet velocity, dn is the nozzle diameter, ρfl, υfl and σfl are the density, kinematic viscosity and surface tension of the liquid fuel.

The number of droplets in a parcel is arrived at from the fuel mass and the representative droplet Sauter mean diameter (SMD) value. The air entrainment (ma,e) into the spray and the evaporation calculations used in this model are presented in Appendix 2.

sec.title: Mixing model
sec.p: In the post-injection phase, the fuel–air mixing is evaluated using turbulent mixing considerations. The air entrained into the spray is evaluated from the available mass of the surrounding charge (msur) and the mixing time (τmix = ϵ/k). Thus
where Cent is a modeling constant determined at the instant of the end of spray mixing.

The major contributing factors to the in-cylinder turbulence generation include in-cylinder fluid motion, injection and combustion. The equations for rates of specific kinetic energy production (k) and dissipation (ϵ) including the effects of these processes are, respectively, expressed following Ikegami et al.12

where C1 and C2 are turbulence model constants, M is the total spray mass estimated from the mass flow rate of the fuel (

The rate of production of turbulent kinetic energy by the spray jet (Gj), air swirl (Gs) and combustion (Gcomb) are estimated following Bhaskar13

where uj and us are the velocity of the fuel jet and charge respectively, ρfl and ρa are the density of the fuel and air, respectively, R is the gas constant,

is the energy release rate, Cp is the specific heat at constant pressure and mcyl is the mass of the charge in the cylinder. η j, η comb and η s represent the conversion efficiencies of injection, combustion and swirl related kinetic energies respectively into turbulent kinetic energy.

sec.title: Combustion model
sec.p: In diesel engines, the combustion is known to occur in two phases, premixed and diffusion phases, in which chemical kinetics and mixing controlled mechanisms are known to be dominant. The premixed phase is characterized on the basis of the amount of fuel injected during the delay period, which is determined using the Hardenberg–Hase correlation14 expressed in CAs as

where Up is the mean piston speed, Ru is the universal gas constant, Tm is the absolute air temperature in the intake manifold, Rc is the compression ratio, n is the polytropic index taken to be 1.34, pm is the absolute pressure in the intake manifold in bar, and EA is the activation energy given in terms of fuel cetane number (CN) as

The choice of the above correlation is based on an assessment wherein the predictions from a few important ignition delay correlations15,16 have been compared for the test conditions investigated. Liu et al.17 also reported the suitability of the Hardenberg–Hase correlation under identical operating conditions in their work. The details of modeling of premixed and mixing controlled combustion are presented in Appendix 3.

sec.title: Engine wall heat transfer
sec.p: Instantaneous wall heat transfer is required to obtain a gross energy release rate from the net energy release estimates made from the combustion model discussed in the previous section, which is estimated using

where As is the instantaneous surface area of the cylinder, and Tg and Tw are the mean temperatures of the cylinder gases and the wall temperature, respectively. In all the cases presented here, the operating conditions are very similar in terms of engine speed and load. Hence, the same wall temperature of 400 K is assumed. The assumption of a temperature of 400 K is based on the equivalence ratio of the referred sources of data. A wall temperature of 400 K is suggested to be a fair assumption for an overall equivalence ratio less than 0.833,18 and applies to the cases investigated here. The wall heat transfer model is presented in Appendix 4.

sec.title: Thermodynamic analysis
sec.p: The thermodynamic analysis carried out for estimating apparent cylinder pressure and temperature histories involves setting up conservation equations of mass and energy and the equation of state for the spray and surrounding regions along with an instantaneous volume constraint.19,20 It is assumed that the properties of the combustion products are the same as those of air. Detailed equations for the two zones are provided in Appendix 5.

sec.title: Emission model
sec.p: In the present analysis, the models required to predict the nitric oxide (NO) and soot particulate emissions under different injection schedules are based on the extended Zeldovich mechanism21 and the multi-process soot formation reaction scheme of Fusco et al.22
For the NO formation mechanism given in Table 1, the rate of NO formation is estimated as

where nNO is the number of moles in the spray volume Vsp and RN1, RN2 and RN3 are the reaction constants in kmol m−3. For the required calculations, the diesel fuel is represented by its widely used surrogate n-dodecane (C12H26). The products of combustion comprise 11 species, CO2, CO, H2O, H2, O2, N2, H, O, OH, NO and N, which are input to the NO and soot kinetic models. The equilibrium concentrations of these species are computed using the Gibbs free energy minimization technique.23

Soot emission is the result of soot formation and oxidation processes. Soot formation in diesel engines is rather complex, and its rate of formation depends on mixing time, equivalence ratio, temperature, and so on. The multi-process soot formation model includes single-step rate kinetics of various soot formation processes such as pyrolysis, surface growth and coagulation (refer to Table 2). The soot oxidation rate is estimated following Morel and Kreibar.24

Considering the important steps in soot formation, the conservation equations are written for precursor and growth species, along with soot number density and volume fraction, as precursor radical concentration, R (kmol m−3)
growth species concentration, C2H2 (kmol m−3)
soot number density, PND (particles m−3)
soot volume fraction, SVF (m3 of soot/m3 of mixture)

where ρ s is the soot density, NA is Avagadro’s number, MC is the molecular weight of the carbon and MR is the molecular weight of the precursor radical. The solution of equations (15) to (18) gives the concentration of the precursor, the growth species, the soot volume fraction and the particle number density.13

sec.title: Model validation
sec.p: The model predictions of instantaneous cylinder pressure, energy release rates and the exhaust concentrations of NO and soot emissions (computed from their instantaneous estimates) for the available4–7 multiple-injection schedules are compared with their measured values. The details concerning engines and the injection schedules used in the referred sources of measured data are given in Tables 3 and 4, respectively.

tr.td: Dwell between pilot and main injection (°CA)
Dwell between pilot and main injection (°CA)
Dwell between main and post injection (°CA)

sec.p: The fuel injection rate profile is obtained by digitizing the fuel mass flow rate from the corresponding sources of data. From the test conditions reported in Table 3, it is observed that the available measured data vary over a wide range of engine cylinder volumes from 470 to 2440 cc, compression ratios from 15 to 19, injection pressures from 780 to 1100 bar and operating speeds of 1500 to 1750 r/min. In addition, these data concern single-, double- andtriple-injection pulses, hence they adequately cover a variety of multiple-injection schedules required for model validation. The data from Pierpont et al.6 are used as a reference case for fine tuning the model constants. The values of these tuned constants are kept unchanged while validating the data referred from other sources.4,5,7 The validation of the proposed combustion and emission model is attempted using the published experimental data on three different engines and a wide range of injection conditions. The predictive ability of the model in respect of combustion and emission characteristics is demonstrated and discussed in the following sections.

sec.title: Combustion characteristics
sec.p: The proposed model is evaluated by comparing the predictions with the measured cylinder pressure data reported by Pierpont et al.6 for single-, double- and triple-injection schedules. The suitable model constants are arrived at by these comparisons (refer to Figure 2) and subsequently used in comparing pressure histories from other sources4,5,7 in order to establish wider applicability of the model. The values of the model constants are given in Table 5. The comparisons of the model predictions are in good agreement with the measured values.

caption.p: Comparison of predicted and measured cylinder pressure histories (Pierpont et al.6).

fn.label: a
fn.p: The superscript number represents the reference number for this choice of constant.

sec.p: Alongside the pressure histories, the energy release rate histories deduced from the measured cylinder pressure data and those predicted from the model for these injection schedules are compared in Figure 3. The qualitative trends from the model predictions match with the measured pressure/energy release rate histories and emission data. However, the overall agreement between the predicted and measured values is found to be good. A slight mismatch between the measured and simulated energy release rate profiles in the case of single injection (Figure 3(a)) and elsewhere could be attributed to the simple model assumptions and the approximations involved in digitizing the fuel injection rate profile from the published sources.

caption.p: Comparison of predicted and measured rate of energy release histories (Pierpont et al.6).

sec.p: The first peak in the instantaneous energy release rate plots corresponds to the energy release rate during the premixed combustion phase, while the other peaks are due to mixing controlled combustion phase. It is worthwhile to note that the peaks of the energy release rates during the premixed combustion phase for the double- and triple-pulse injection schedules are lower than those for single injection. This is attributed to the significantly lower quantity of fuel accumulated and ignited in the premixed mode during almost identical ignition delays of around 5° CA in each case.

It is noted from the model calculations that the ignitable mixture prepared during the delay period in the single-injection case is three-quarters that of the fuel injected during the delay. The amount of ignitable mixture prepared in the double and triple injections is about one-third that of the single-injection case, but almost all the fuel injected during the ignition delay remains within ignitable limits. It is thus evident that the split injection reduces the energy release rates during premixed combustion. Furthermore, it is observed that the number of energy release peaks during the mixing controlled combustion phase increases in the case of multiple injections, depending on the number of pulses in the injection schedule. The additional energy releases due to post-injection pulses are reported2,7 to enhance the in-cylinder turbulence controlling air–fuel mixing and the soot oxidation in the later phase of the combustion.

Comparisons of the predicted cylinder pressure and energy release rate histories from the model with the measured pressure and energy release data of Tow et al.7 for the double and triple injections with a very different injection timing on the same engine as Pierpont et al.6 are shown in Figures 4 and 5, respectively. Similarly, the comparisons of measured pressure and energy release rate histories of different multiple-injection schedules provided in the work of Tennison and Reitz4 with the model predictions are shown in Figures 6 and 7, respectively. Figure 8 shows a comparison of predicted and measured cylinder pressure histories by Hasse et al.5

caption.p: Comparison of predicted and measured cylinder pressure histories (Tow et al.7).
Comparison of predicted and measured rate of energy release histories (Tow et al.7).
Comparison of predicted and measured cylinder pressure histories with Adiff = 2.3 (Tennison and Reitz4).
Comparison of predicted and measured rate of energy release histories with Adiff = 2.3 (Tennison and Reitz4).
Comparison of predicted and measured cylinder pressure histories (Hasse et al.5).

sec.p: The overall agreements between predicted and the measured cylinder pressure histories in all these cases are found to be good. However, with the same model constant, Adiff, it is observed that for data of Tennison and Reitz4 at an operating speed of 1757 r/min, which is higher than that of Pierpont et al.,6 do not provide as good an agreement in the pressure and energy release rate histories and emission values as in the other sets of data. This indicated the possible sensitivity of the model constant to the speed variations. This fact was examined by varying the model constant, and it is observed that Adiff = 2.3 provided better agreement between the measured and predicted values of the pressure and energy release rate histories and emissions for the Tennison and Reitz4 data. The dependence of the model constant on speed requires further investigations with measured data over a wide range of engine speeds. However, the present work adequately demonstrates the applicability of a simple and fast phenomenological model for multiple-injection CRDI engines and its potential for optimizing injection schedule in a CRDI engine.

For understanding the combustion behavior of multiple-injection process, the predicted energy release curves for the Pierpont et al.6 data, shown in Figure 9, are quite revealing. As expected, the relative variations in energy release rates are clearly evident in the cases of different injection pulses. It is observed that the combustion duration referred with respect to 90% of the fuel burnt amount seems to be more or less identical in single- and double-pulse injections. In the triple-injection case, the combustion duration extends over a longer period than the single- and double-injection pulses, but, discounting the dwell period between the pulses in the triple-injection case, the duration seems to appear slightly lower than the other injection pulses. With regards to the energy release rates, it is observed that in the early phase of the single injection, the energy release rate is steeper than that of the double- and triple-injection cases. The initial burning rate is slower in the double-injection case than that in the triple-injection case. Subsequently, the double-injection rate tends to approach the single-injection rate, while the triple-injection pulse remains lower than the single and double injection.

caption.p: Predicted cumulative energy release curves for the injection schedules of Pierpont et al.6

sec.p: From these comparisons of the model predictions with the range of experimental data from different sources, it is evident that the proposed two-zone phenomenological model has captured the essential physics to provide quantitative estimates of the combustion characteristics (cylinder gas pressure histories) of single- and multiple-injection diesel engines for a variety of injection schedules.

The emission predictions from the model are discussed in the following section. The amount of fuel injected during each pulse in a given injection schedule and the dwell between the pulses are expected to influence the combustion characteristics, and hence the model like the one presented here facilitates a priori estimation of a suitable schedule for any engine operating condition.

sec.title: Emission characteristics
sec.p: he effects of single- and multiple-injection schedule on the in-cylinder NO and soot particulates are predicted from the proposed emission model formulation. The predicted results of NO and soot emissions are compared with their measured exhaust concentrations reported by Pierpont et al.6 and Tow et al.7 Figures 10 and 11 show comparisons of predicted NO and soot particulate emissions with experimental results for the available single- and multiple-injection schedules,4–7 respectively.

caption.p: Comparison of nitric oxide and soot particulate emissions.
Comparison of predicted and measured nitric oxide and particulate emissions.

sec.p: Figure 10 provides the time histories of NO and soot particulate for the single-injection case, and the frozen NO concentration at the end of the expansion are compared with the measured values. Due to low in-cylinder gas temperatures during the later part of the expansion, the in-cylinder NO concentration remains comparable with the measured exhaust NO values,25 and the same has been observed here. It is clearly evident from the time history of NO predictions that there is predominance of NO kinetics during the premixed phase of combustion.

The soot kinetics, particularly its oxidation, extends beyond the mixing-controlled combustion phase into the exhaust period, and thus results in considerably low soot concentration in the engine exhaust. As shown in Figure 10, the predicted exhaust soot concentration at bottom dead center (BDC) seems comparable with the measured engine exhaust soot concentrations reported by Pierpont et al.6 and Tow et al.7 in their investigations. These comparisons show the good agreement between estimated and measured NO and soot emissions. The slight over predictions of soot concentrations are attributed to the fact that there must have been some oxidation of soot particulates beyond BDC, the point of comparison here. These comparisons demonstrate a satisfactory predictive ability of the two-zone formulation that could be used for the study of parametric dependence of the injection schedule on NO and soot emissions.

Figure 11 shows a comparison of the predicted NO and soot particulate concentrations with the measured values for the multiple-injection schedules.4–7 The qualitative trends of both NO and soot concentrations for various multiple-injection schedules investigated are found to be encouraging for the simplicity of the model. There is much closer agreement between predicted and measured NO emission than the soot concentrations, which are quite over predicted, as explained earlier.

sec.title: Parametric investigations
sec.p: The amount of fuel injected during pilot injection in a given schedule and the dwell between the pilot and main injections are reported to have an influence on the combustion and emission characteristics. The results of the parametric investigations using the proposed two-zone model in this regard are discussed here.

sec.title: Effect of pilot fuel quantity on combustion and emission
sec.p: In order to study the effect of pilot fuel quantity on combustion and NO and soot particulate emissions, injection schedule 48 (10) 52 of Tow et al.7 is chosen as a reference. The schedule specification, 48 (10) 52, represents the percentage of fuel injected during pilot injection, the dwell between pilot and main injection (in parentheses) and the percentage of fuel injected during the main injection, respectively. For parametric investigations, the pilot quantity of fuel is varied from 36% to 70% in definite increments, and the corresponding results concerning peak pressure and its occurrence, NO and soot particulate concentrations are shown in Figures 12 and 13, respectively. An increase in pilot fuel quantity increases the peak cylinder gas pressures and retards its occurrence, as can be seen in Figure 12. These observations corroborate with the experimental results of Nehmer and Reitz.26

caption.p: Effect of pilot fuel quantity on combustion.
Effect of pilot fuel quantity on emissions.

sec.p: Figure 13 shows the effect of pilot fuel quantity on NO and soot particulate concentrations. It is observed that there is an increase in NO and a decrease in soot particulate concentrations with increasing amount of pilot fuel. It is important to note that while there is a steady increase in NO, the decrease in soot particulates is rapid beyond a certain pilot fuel quantity, which happens to be 48% in the present case. The predicted results corroborate the reduction of particulates and increase of NO due to increases in pilot fuel quantity, as reported in the literature.2,8,26,27 The NO increase has a direct bearing with an increase in the energy release rate during the premixed combustion phase, with an increasing pilot fuel quantity. The consequent reduction in mixing controlled combustion phase substantiates the reduction in soot concentration. Thus, a trade-off between NO and soot emissions requires the optimization of pilot fuel quantity for a particular engine configuration and condition.

sec.title: Effect of dwell between pilot and main injection
sec.p: To ascertain the effect of dwell time, the same injection schedule as in the above case has been taken as a reference. The dwell period between the pilot and main injection is varied from 6° to 20° CA. The variation of soot particulate emission with respect to the change in dwell between pilot and main injection is predicted to maintain a constant NO level by adjusting the start of injection with the specified pilot duration. Figure 14 shows the predicted variations of soot emission with respect to the dwell between pilot and main injection. It is important to mention that the predicted NO level for these cases remained within 6 ± 0.25 g/kWh. It is observed that the optimum dwell period between pilot and main injection for minimum soot concentration at a fixed NO level is 12° CA. The qualitative trend of this prediction for this injection schedule corroborates well with the experimental results of Tow et al.7 and shows the ability of the present model.

caption.p: Effect of dwell between pilot and main injection on soot particulate emission.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A two-zone phenomenological model for estimation of combustion, NO and soot particulate emissions for CRDI engines has been developed. The model considers the premixed and mixing controlled phases of diesel combustion through spray development and turbulent mixing formulations applicable to multiple-injection cases. The model constants are evaluated based on the measured combustion and emission data of Pierpont et al.6 The model is subsequently validated over a large set of injection schedules available in the literature for different CRDI engines. Comparisons between the predicted and measured data show good agreement over a wide range of conditions. The predictive ability of the model is demonstrated by studying the effect of pilot fuel quantity and dwell between the pilot and main injection pulses by corroborating with the measured trends reported in the published literature. The present model can be a useful tool for optimizing the multiple-injection schedule for different CRDI engines.

sec.title: Spray model
sec.p: The air entrainment (ma, e) into the spray is related to fuel injection rate as

The spray penetration (S) is obtained from empirical correlations29 given as

The actual mass of evaporated fuel from a parcel is arrived at from the change in size of the droplets in that parcel. Thus, the total mass of evaporated fuel (mfv) at a given time step is

where subscript i represents a parcel and subscript j represents the time step. So, Di, j is the diameter of the ith parcel at the jth time interval, and Ndi is the number of droplets in the ith parcel.

sec.title: Premixed combustion phase
sec.p: The fuel injected during the ignition delay period evaporates and mixes with the entrained air and produces a premixed charge. The requirement of oxygen moles participating in the premixed combustion is obtained from the rate of air entrainment into the spray. The amount of fuel participating in the premixed combustion phase is the amount of ignitable mixture prepared, meaning that the instantaneous fuel–air equivalence ratio ranges from 0.3 to 3.31 Since the burning of this premixed fuel–air charge is kinetically controlled, the maximum chemical reaction rate can be estimated based on bi-molecular reaction kinetics.32 Thus, the rate of premixed burning is

where Apre is a model constant for premixed combustion phase, ρ mix is the mixture density,
X
fv
and
X
o
2
are the mole fraction of the evaporated fuel and oxygen, respectively, and T and V are instantaneous spray temperature and volume, respectively.

sec.title: Mixing controlled combustion phase
sec.p: As soon as the amount of premixed fuel–air charge accumulated during the ignition delay period is consumed, the combustion enters the mixing controlled phase.33 In diffusion flames, fuel and oxygen occur in separate eddies. Due to the rapid chemical reactions, it can be assumed that the rate of burning is controlled by the rate of intermixing on a molecular scale of fuel and oxygen eddies. This combustion phase is modeled based on the eddy dissipation concept.33 The model derived from Magnussen and Hjertager is the most commonly used model in multi-dimensional diesel combustion computations,34–36 and hence the rate of mixing controlled burning is

where Adiff is a model constant for diffusion combustion,
m
o
2
is the mass of oxygen and (O2/f)st is the stoichiometric oxygen fuel ratio.

sec.title: Wall heat transfer model
sec.p: The instantaneous heat transfer coefficient h(t) is obtained using the Hohenberg correlation37

where h1 is the heat transfer model constant with a chosen value of 130. The mean cylinder gas temperature Tg(t) is a mass weighted mean temperature of the spray fluids (Tsp) and the surroundings gas (Tsur) and evaluated as

The heat transfer from the spray (Qht, sp) and surroundings (Qht, sur) are evaluated by apportioning the total heat transfer based on the instantaneous mass and temperature values of the two regions; that is, spray and surroundings, respectively, and are represented as
where dQht is the instantaneous heat transfer from the cylinder gas to the wall.

sec.title: Mass conservation for the whole spray
sec.p: The rate of change of mass in the spray is the fuel injection rate plus the air entrainment rate into the spray
This is further subdivided into:

list-item.p: the rate of change of mass of liquid fuel in the spray, which equals the fuel injection rate minus the fuel evaporation rate
the rate of change of fuel vapor mass in the spray, which equals the fuel evaporation rate minus the fuel burning rate
the rate of change of air mass in the spray, which equals the air entrainment rate minus the air consumption rate due to combustion
the rate of change of mass of combustion products in the spray, which equals the fuel burning rate plus the air consumption rate due to combustion

sec.title: Mass conservation for the surroundings
sec.p: The rate of change mass in the surroundings equals minus the rate of air entrainment into the spray

sec.title: Energy conservation
sec.p: Each of the energy conservation equations will follow from

sec.title: Energy conservation for the spray zone
Equation of state for the spray zone
Equation of state for the surroundings
sec.p: where m is mass, R is the gas constant and Cv is the specific heat at constant volume. The instantaneous cylinder pressure, temperature and volume are represented by p, T and V, respectively. Qc and Qht are the energy release due to combustion and the wall heat loss, respectively.

To obtain rate of change of Tsp, Tsur, p and Vsp, the four ordinary differential equations (44) to (47) comprising energy conservation and the equation of state for the spray and surrounding regions are solved simultaneously using the MATLAB program. This solution has to satisfy the instantaneous volume constraint equation

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
